Line 127: Line 127:      
====Eros====
 
====Eros====
−
[[Eros]], [[passionate love]], was originally defined by [[Plato]] as desire for and appreciation of the beautiful. One is only truely lovable if they have 'goodness', and eros is the apprecation of the true beauty within a person.
+
[[Eros]] is passionate love, with sensual desire and longing.
  +   +
[[Plato]] refined his own definition. Although eros is initially felt for a person, with contemplation it becomes an appreciation of the beauty within that person, or even become appreciation of beauty itself. Eros helps the soul recall knowledge of beauty, and contributes to an understanding of spiritual truth. Lovers, artists, and philosophers are all inspired to seek truth by eros.
     
====Philia====
 
====Philia====
−
[[Philia]], [[friendship]], was developed by [[Aristotle]]. It includes loyalty to friends, family, and community. Philia is motivated by practical reasons; one or both of the parties benefit from the relationship. Philia is generally reciprocal.
+
[[Philia]], a dispassionate virtuous love, was developed by [[Aristotle]]. It includes loyalty to friends, family, and community, and requires virtue, equality and familiarity. Philia is motivated by practical reasons; one or both of the parties benefit from the relationship.
     
====Storge====
 
====Storge====
Line 143: Line 143:  
[[Christianity|Christians]] believe that love to God and to other people (God's creation, as they see it) are the two most important things in life (the greatest commandment of God, according to [[Jesus Christ]]. See The [[Gospel of Mark]] chapter 12, verses 28-34 in the [[Bible]]). [[Saint Augustine]] summarised this when he wrote "Love God, and do as thou wilt". Many Christian [[Theology|theologists]] see God as the source of love which is mirrored in humans and their relationships.
 
[[Christianity|Christians]] believe that love to God and to other people (God's creation, as they see it) are the two most important things in life (the greatest commandment of God, according to [[Jesus Christ]]. See The [[Gospel of Mark]] chapter 12, verses 28-34 in the [[Bible]]). [[Saint Augustine]] summarised this when he wrote "Love God, and do as thou wilt". Many Christian [[Theology|theologists]] see God as the source of love which is mirrored in humans and their relationships.
    −
====Agape====
+
====Agapē====
−
In the [[New Testament]], [[Agape]], or 'Christian love' is charitable, selfless, altruistic, and unconditional. Its fatherly love seen as creating goodness in the world, and is reciprocal between believers and God.
+
In the [[New Testament]], [[Agapē]], is charitable, selfless, altruistic, and unconditional. Its fatherly love seen as creating goodness in the world, and is reciprocal between believers and God.
     
====Nomos====
 
====Nomos====
−
[[Nomos]] is devotion to God, and the subjugation of the will before Him and His divine law. In this view, God is the only one worthy of love.
+
[[Nomos]] is devotion to God, and the subjugation of the will before Him and His divine law.
